quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Fall in love, fall in love, fall in love, fall in love with the problem, and then actually what you're trying to do is engage everyone else to fall in love with the same problem, to go into this journey, into this path and follow your leadership there.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A crisp founder framework: prioritize deep problem obsession and align the team around the problem (not the solution) to drive leadership and momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Every time that you hire someone new, mark your calendars for 30 days down the road and ask yourself one question, knowing what I know today, would I hire this person? If the answer is no, fire them immediately.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A concrete, time-boxed hiring/firing methodology that forces fast correction of bad hires before costs compound.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Most people are missing the most important slide of their presentation is the first slide. This slide is going to be presented for the longest period of time. This is the place that you're going to put your strongest point. Now the second most important slide is the last one.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A counterintuitive pitch-deck prioritization rule: optimize for the slides that get the most attention and determine first/last impressions.

quotes.topic_title: Fall in love with the problem
quotes.text: at the end of the day, the entrepreneurship journey is about value creation. The simplest way to create value is solve a problem.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for founders: anchor entrepreneurship in value creation by starting with a real problem.

quotes.topic_title: Fall in love with the problem
quotes.text: when you fall in love with the problem, then what happened is that the problem is going to serve as the North Star of your journey, and when you have a North Star, you're going to make less deviation from the course and you are way more likely to become successful.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Frames the problem as a “North Star” that reduces strategic drift and increases odds of success.

quotes.topic_title: Fall in love with the problem
quotes.text: Just imagine that we will be here in 2007, just before I started Waze, and I will tell you I'm going to build an AI crowd-source based navigation system and you're going to say, "Oh, yeah, very interesting," but you don't care. If I will tell you I'm going to help you to avoid traffic jams, then you do care, and when your customer cares, they want you to be successful, and when they want you to be successful, they are going to help you to become successful.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A concrete example showing why leading with the problem/value (not the tech) makes your story compelling and recruits customer support.

quotes.topic_title: Fall in love with the problem
quotes.text: Think of a problem, a big problem, something that it's worth solving, something that the world will become a better place if you solve that and then ask yourself, so who has this problem?
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: An actionable sequence for startup discovery: pick a meaningful problem, then identify who experiences it.

quotes.topic_title: Fall in love with the problem
quotes.text: But generally speaking, if you start your story with that, you focus on your solution. If you start with the story with, "The problem we are solving is," Then you focus on the problem. If your story start with, "The value that we create for you is," then you focus on the user. The last two are way better than focus on the solution.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A practical communication framework for pitches and emails: lead with problem or user value rather than the solution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers and automate compliance For SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA and more with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concise operational framework for consolidating risk assessment, customer trust, and compliance automation into one system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risk, plus you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable advice on shifting compliance from point-in-time audits to continuous monitoring while reducing manual questionnaire work with AI.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Most founders and finance teams have to couple together a patchwork of tools to reconcile transactions from different sources, work extra hard just to get a holistic view of cashflow and have maps to company priorities and struggle to get answers from platforms that all speak different languages.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear problem diagnosis describing why finance ops becomes inefficient: fragmented tools, poor cashflow visibility, and incompatible systems.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With new bill pay and accounting capabilities, you can pay bills faster, stay in control of company spend and speed up reconciliation.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Practical, implementable levers for improving finance operations: faster bill pay, tighter spend control, and quicker reconciliation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You talked about like, make sure enough people have this problem versus just getting a therapist that's going to help you with this problem.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for founders: validate market size by distinguishing scalable problems from highly personal ones.

quotes.topic_title: Validating problem size and founder passion
quotes.text: So people ask me, "So you send me to speak with users. How many?" And I will tell them a hundred. You don't need a hundred, but the hundred basically say you need to get out of your comfort zone.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for validating problem size by forcing founders to talk beyond their immediate network.

quotes.topic_title: Validating problem size and founder passion
quotes.text: It's not just your close friends and family that you need to discuss that. You need to discuss that with people that you don't know.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Emphasizes unbiased validation by prioritizing conversations with strangers over supportive insiders.

quotes.topic_title: Validating problem size and founder passion
quotes.text: If you tell someone, "This is the problem I'm going to address," and they will tell you, "Oh, I know someone that has this problem," it's not a real problem.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A counterintuitive litmus test: secondhand recognition suggests the pain isn’t immediate or widespread enough.

quotes.topic_title: Validating problem size and founder passion
quotes.text: If they will tell you, "No, no, no, no, no. This is not the problem. The problem is," and they will give you their description of the problem. This is something that you really want to follow.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A strong signal of real pain: users correct you and articulate the problem in their own words.

quotes.topic_title: Validating problem size and founder passion
quotes.text: You look at one of the most successful products in the world, the iPhone, right? And you ask yourself, what was exactly the problem when they started? And the answer is that there was no problem when they started.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Challenges the default “must solve an existing problem” rule by highlighting invention-driven success cases.

quotes.topic_title: Pivot example: Oversee from B2C to B2B
quotes.text: So if this is the price that you paid and this is cancellation fees, if the price drops here, you can rebook the same flight at the cheaper price.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A concrete mechanism for creating customer value by exploiting post-purchase price volatility and rebooking economics.

quotes.topic_title: Pivot example: Oversee from B2C to B2B
quotes.text: we realized that even though the people really care, they are not willing to take the action that is required, and we ended up with doing that for corporates, and in corporates there are very simple ways for them to engage that automatically, so automatic rebooking and so forth, and we can save corporates about 10% of the travel budget that goes directly to bottom line.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A pivot lesson: if users won’t take required actions, move to a segment where the workflow can be automated and ROI is explicit.

quotes.topic_title: Pivot example: Oversee from B2C to B2B
quotes.text: So we started that as a B2C and then we realized that this is way harder than we think it is, and we ended up with converting that into B2B, which turns out to be very successful for us.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A succinct pivot narrative showing how switching business model/segment can unlock adoption and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Pivot example: Oversee from B2C to B2B
quotes.text: And so occasionally there are companies that you start your journey with one perception and you change that and that will happen multiple times.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A mental model that reframes pivots as a normal, repeated part of company-building rather than a one-time event.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas and embracing failure
quotes.text: So for me, it's usually personal frustration that leads me to start to think about it, whether or not we can change it.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A practical method for sourcing startup ideas: start from a problem that personally frustrates you enough to pursue change.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas and embracing failure
quotes.text: But in general, look, the problem itself needs to start from you, right? Something that really bothers you, something that you care about, and then it's the validations of the problem that you speak with many people, try to realize.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A simple idea-to-validation workflow: begin with personal pain, then validate by talking to many target users.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas and embracing failure
quotes.text: The second conclusion is that you really want to fail fast.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A core operating principle for startups: optimize for speed of learning by failing quickly and moving to the next attempt.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas and embracing failure
quotes.text: The biggest enemy of good enough is perfect.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A memorable counter to perfectionism that encourages shipping and iterating toward market-winning quality.

quotes.topic_title: Finding startup ideas and embracing failure
quotes.text: When you start as a startup, you don't have a product. You don't know what's the business model. You don't know what people are going to pay you for. You don't know how to grow your business, and you need to figure out all of those, and this is going to be a long journey.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A reality-check mental model: startups begin with unknowns across product, pricing, and growth, and must discover them over time.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit: retention as the metric
quotes.text: When you start as a startup, you don't have a product. You don't know what's the business model. You don't know what people are going to pay you for. You don't know how to grow your business, and you need to figure out all of those, and this is going to be a long journey.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Clarifies the core startup job as discovering (not executing) product, business model, pricing, and growth—setting expectations for a long PMF search.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit: retention as the metric
quotes.text: Now, the longest part is usually figuring out product market fit and product market fit is really simple. That means that you create value to your customers. If you do not figure out product market fit, you will die. As simple as that.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Defines PMF as customer value creation and frames it as existential—useful for prioritizing PMF above all else.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit: retention as the metric
quotes.text: So once a company figure out product market fit, they don't change their product anymore because this is the value that they created to the customers and you don't want to change that.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Counterintuitive claim that post-PMF success often comes from stabilizing around the core value proposition rather than constant product change.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit: retention as the metric
quotes.text: For Waze, it was four years. For Microsoft, it was five years. For Netflix, it was 10 years.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Concrete time-to-PMF examples that reset expectations for how long value creation can take.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit: retention as the metric
quotes.text: Now, at the end of the day, product market fit have one metric. One metric. That's it. Retention. That's really simple. If you create value, they will come back. If they're not coming back, that means that you are not creating value.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Provides a single-metric PMF test practitioners can apply immediately: measure retention as the proxy for value.

quotes.topic_title: Waze PMF journey: global launch and iterations
quotes.text: We made Waze global at the end of 2009 and we expect that to work the same way that it did in Israel, but it didn't. It was not good enough. It was not good enough in the U.S. It was not good enough in Western Europe. It was not good enough in Latin America, it was not good enough in Asia. It was not good enough anywhere that matters, right?
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A concrete reminder that early success in one market doesn’t generalize—PMF must be re-earned market-by-market.

quotes.topic_title: Waze PMF journey: global launch and iterations
quotes.text: So people downloaded the app and it simply was not good enough. So they churned, right, because if it's not good enough, you're not coming back. We spoke with them. We asked them what didn't work for them. They told us because they wanted it to work, and we built the next version addressing everything that they've told us, and we know that this is it, and it's not.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: An actionable iteration loop: use churn + user interviews to drive each release, while expecting false “this is it” convictions.

quotes.topic_title: Waze PMF journey: global launch and iterations
quotes.text: Iteration after iteration after iteration after iteration. More than a year of iterations until beginning of 2011 that we actually started to see that working, and then it's in multiple places. In the U.S., one metropolitan after the other, right? Los Angeles first and then San Francisco and then Washington D.C. and Chicago and New York and Atlanta and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A specific scaling pattern and timeline: sustained iteration, then sequential rollout city-by-city once it starts working.

quotes.topic_title: Waze PMF journey: global launch and iterations
quotes.text: And then the house number two can be miles away, but it's the second oldest house in the neighborhood and so you have to have all the house numbers unless... Until then you are not good enough. And crowdsource is, if you need perfect information, crowdsource may not be the right way to do that.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A counterintuitive constraint: crowdsourcing breaks down when the domain requires near-perfect completeness (illustrated by Japan’s addressing system).

quotes.topic_title: Waze retention heuristics and value of certainty
quotes.text: we tried to compare everything to Israel, so we looked at the frequency of use or when our people are coming back. How long does it take them until the next try and until the next try.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A practical benchmarking method: anchor new-market retention/frequency expectations to a known “home” baseline and measure time-between-uses.

quotes.topic_title: Waze retention heuristics and value of certainty
quotes.text: in generally speaking, if you look at something that have high frequency of use, then you will be looking at three-month retentions of 30, 40, 50% is actually pretty good indication.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Provides concrete retention targets for high-frequency consumer products as an early signal of product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Waze retention heuristics and value of certainty
quotes.text: But usually what would happen is that you would know when they convert and that's going to be after the third or the fourth time, and if they're not getting to the fourth time, then they are basically saying, "Okay. We gave it a try. We really like this story. We gave it another try, and it's not good enough."
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A memorable conversion heuristic: focus on getting users to the 3rd/4th use as the make-or-break threshold.

quotes.topic_title: Waze retention heuristics and value of certainty
quotes.text: It's about creating certainty and certainty is way higher value than saving time.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Counterintuitive value proposition shift: users may value predictability more than optimization, changing what you prioritize in product design.

quotes.topic_title: Waze retention heuristics and value of certainty
quotes.text: "If I am living in Cupertino and I need to drive up to San Francisco and I can take 101 or 280, I don't really want to change my route unless there is something dramatic, but what I really want to know is how long it's going to take me. So I'm going to stay on the 101. I'm not going to get into service road. I'm not going to take El Camino Real. I'm not going to try something else. I'm going to stay on the 101. Just let me know how long it's going to take."
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A concrete user example showing that “certainty” can beat “fastest route,” informing how to message and optimize navigation products.

quotes.topic_title: Startup phases and shifting focus over time
quotes.text: If you don't figure out product market fit, you will die. If you do, then you get to live and die another day and the other day is whether or not you're going to figure out how to grow your business and whether or not you're going to figure out your business model.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A stark prioritization framework: PMF is existential first, and only after that do growth and monetization become the next battles.

quotes.topic_title: Startup phases and shifting focus over time
quotes.text: When we started Waze, we thought that we're going to sell map data and traffic information and we ended up with doing advertisement. Very different business model.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A concrete example showing that business model discovery can radically change over time even if the product succeeds.

quotes.topic_title: Startup phases and shifting focus over time
quotes.text: Word-of-mouth you can only have if you have high frequency of use.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth heuristic that ties virality to usage cadence rather than just product quality.

quotes.topic_title: Startup phases and shifting focus over time
quotes.text: If you do that, if you try to do multiple things at the same time, you will fail. Focus is not about what we are doing, it's about what we are not doing. These are the hard decisions.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A memorable operating principle for phase-based execution: shifting gears requires explicit tradeoffs and saying no.

quotes.topic_title: Startup phases and shifting focus over time
quotes.text: If you don't have high frequency of use, you are sentenced to acquire users or customers all of your lifetime.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A provocative framing that forces teams to confront whether their product can ever get “free” growth or will require perpetual paid/active acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Census had a 10x increase in pipeline with the LinkedIn startup team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete case study showing potential pipeline impact from partnering with LinkedIn’s startup team.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For Webflow, after ramping up on LinkedIn in Q4, they had the highest marketing source revenue quarter to date.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Example of a measurable outcome tied to increasing LinkedIn investment over a specific period.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With LinkedIn Ads, you'll have direct access to and can build relationships with decision makers including 950 million members, 180 million senior execs and over 10 million C-level executives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable positioning for B2B marketers: prioritize channels where decision-makers are directly reachable at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In tech, LinkedIn generated two to five x higher return on ad spend than any other social media platforms.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Comparative performance benchmark that can inform channel allocation decisions for B2B tech advertisers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You'll be able to drive results with targeting and measurement tools built specifically for B2B.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Practical guidance to choose ad platforms with B2B-specific targeting and measurement capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising realities and pitch slide tactics
quotes.text: And if we say that building a startup is a roller coaster journey, then I will say raising capital is a roller coaster journey in the dark.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that sets expectations for uncertainty and repeated volatility in fundraising.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising realities and pitch slide tactics
quotes.text: And we were sitting in a small meeting room, so the guy is looking at me and then looking at the door and looking at me again and say, "It's before they sit down."
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Highlights how fast investor judgments form, implying founders must optimize for immediate first impressions.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising realities and pitch slide tactics
quotes.text: Now if this is the case and you're looking to raise capital, start with the strongest point at the beginning.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: Direct tactical advice for pitch structure based on first-impression dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising realities and pitch slide tactics
quotes.text: The other part is that they need to tell a good story, and good story is not about facts. It's about creating emotional engagement.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A practical framework for early-stage pitching: prioritize emotional resonance over information density.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising realities and pitch slide tactics
quotes.text: So you're going to hear a hundred times no until you hear one yes.
quotes.speaker: Uri Levine
quotes.context: A concrete expectation-setting data point that reframes rejection as the normal fundraising baseline.
